context: As of 2025, Broadcom is firmly established as one of the largest technology companies globally with a $1+ trillion market cap. The company generates 58% of revenue from semiconductors and 42% from infrastructure software. In semiconductors, Broadcom is a leader in custom AI ASICs (helping hyperscalers like Google, Meta, ByteDance develop specialized AI chips), networking solutions transitioning to Ethernet-based open networking, and wireless connectivity. The company secured a multi-year deal with OpenAI to develop next-generation AI accelerators (revenue starting late 2026). In software, Broadcom manages the massive VMware, CA Technologies, Symantec, and Brocade portfolios, though facing challenges with VMware pricing transitions driving customers to explore alternatives.

competitors.name: Nvidia
competitors.notes: Dominant competitor in general-purpose AI GPUs; Broadcom differentiates with custom AI ASICs that are task-specific and more energy efficient

competitors.name: AMD
competitors.notes: Major AI and data center competitor; stock up 70% in 2025 vs Broadcom's 45% gain; trades at similar P/E multiples (AMD 32x vs AVGO 33.5x)

competitors.name: Intel
competitors.notes: Semiconductor competitor in data center, networking, and connectivity solutions, though Broadcom leads in networking chips

competitors.name: Marvell Technology
competitors.notes: Direct competitor in custom AI chips, data center networking, and infrastructure semiconductors

competitors.name: Qualcomm
competitors.notes: Competitor in wireless communications and mobile semiconductors

competitors.name: Nutanix
competitors.notes: Critical VMware alternative gaining traction as customers seek alternatives due to Broadcom's VMware pricing changes
